I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  In  April  2004,  during  the  Country  Strategy  and  Program  Update  Mission,  the 
Government of the Fiji Islands requested Asian Development Bank (ADB) technical assistance 
(TA)  to  prepare  the  Rural  and  Outer  Islands  Development  Project.  The  ADB  Fact-Finding 
Mission visited the Fiji Islands from 21 to 24 March 2005, and reached an agreement with the 
Government  on  the  TA’s  rationale,  objective,  scope,  cost  estimates,  financing  plan, 
implementation  arrangements,  and  terms  of  reference  for  consulting  services.  The  project 
preparatory TA design is based on the Mission's discussions with the Government; observations 
in the field; and a review of data, studies, and reports. The design and monitoring framework is 
in Appendix 1.1  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The Fiji Islands’ 320 islands are scattered across 150,000 square kilometers in the 
South Pacific Ocean. About 75% of the population of 825,000 lives on the main islands of Viti 
Levu and Vanua Levu, and the remaining reside in about 106 small scattered outer islands 
including the Gau, Kadavu, Koro, Lau group, Taveuni, and Yasawa group. Most of the smaller 
outer islands are sparsely populated—many with only a few hundred people—and isolated.  
 
3.  While the Fiji Islands’ overall socioeconomic condition has improved significantly over 
the last three decades, considerable disparities still exist in terms of economic development and 
distribution of wealth and benefits between the main population centers and the remote rural 
areas and outer islands. Currently, economic activities are concentrated around the urban 
centers and the sugarcane-growing areas of the main islands, and there is a large income 
inequality between urban and rural areas and between the main islands and outer islands. 
Indications  are  that  this  income  inequality  is  increasing.  With  limited  income-earning 
opportunities  in  remote  rural  and  outer  island  areas,  which  have  been  traditionally  on 
subsistence economy, the gap between those in cash and those in subsistence economy 
widens. As a result, in the Lau Group of Islands, the Gini averaged just over 0.3 compared with 
0.46 nationally.2  
 
4.  Political instability in the past has been directly linked to income inequality and poor 
economic growth. Lack of institutional capability at local level in the remoter areas has also 
resulted  in  poor  delivery  of  services  and  income-earning  opportunities.  Thus,  improving 
governance by strengthening local capacity is key to efficient delivery of services and poverty 
reduction. Further, to improve the rural and outer islands economy, involving the private sector 
in feasible areas is critical.   
 
5.  Rural and outer islands development is crucial to promoting balanced development of 
remote communities. The outer islands possess natural resources, including forestry, fishery, 
and agriculture, and have good tourism potential. Subsistence agriculture is the mainstay of the 
economy of the rural and outer islands. However, most people depend on copra and kava for 
cash income. Tourism is an important growth industry and revenue earner in some islands, such 
as  Kadavu  and  Taveuni,  where  the  combination  of  natural  beauty  and  traditional  lifestyle 
provides much of interest to foreign tourists. Trade between islands is dominated by copra and 
other  basic  household  items.  In  most  areas,  goods  are  transported  to  small  islands  by 
interisland or coastal vessels. In some islands, high-value commodities, such as kava, are 
transported by air. There is potential for private sector led joint ventures with local entrepreneurs

in sustainable tourism and marine resources development in the outer islands. Recent market 
projections indicate a steady growth in the tourism sector, which will also lead to demand for 
local fruits, vegetables, fish and other marine products. Previous lack of economic opportunities 
has resulted in a low level of skills in the remote communities, including technical, managerial, 
and entrepreneurial skills. Development of such skills will be essential to enabling the people to 
take advantage of new opportunities. 
 
6.  The  remote  areas  have  tremendous  potential  for  tourism,  marine,  and  agriculture 
development; however, because of the lack of investment in physical infrastructure development 
and income-earning opportunities over the years, people have migrated towards the urban 
centers in the main islands. This has placed a severe strain on the urban centers, with ever-
growing squatter settlements and the associated social problems. The remote communities, 
especially in the outer islands, face chronically inadequate water supply and storage, poor road 
access, irregular shipping and air services, poor telecommunications, lack of electricity and 
other basic services, and limited income-generating opportunities due to poor market access 
and high transportation costs. Existing infrastructure facilities, such as jetties, rural roads, small 
fish and agriculture processing facilities, were mostly built between the mid-1960s and 1980s, 
but since then the lack of investment has severely hampered growth.3 Although the country’s 
shipping and air services network is generally quite well developed, services to many outer 
islands are often nonviable and therefore irregular. This presents a major challenge.  
 
7.  The Government recognizes the need to improve intra-island infrastructure, including 
transportation and communication, to facilitate growth, but so far there is little investment in 
rehabilitation and upgrading of basic facilities in the outer islands. The Strategic Development 
Plan  2003−2005,  and  the  20−year  Development  Plan  (2001−2020),  emphasize  reducing 
disparities between the main island and outer islands through systematic development and 
implementation of programs, including basic social services, related infrastructure, and income-
earning  opportunities  to  reduce  poverty.  The  Government  is  keen  on  formulating  various 
development programs to improve and balance economic growth and to promote rural and outer 
islands development.  
 
8.  There is an immediate need to improve landing facilities (ship docks, small jetties, boat 
channels); expedite loading and unloading; and reduce cargo spoilage, passenger discomfort, 
and injury. Warehousing, mainly for copra but also for general inward cargo, and improvements 
to road tracks are needed to concentrate on copra collection and distribution of inward cargo at 
selected loading points. Navigation aids to enable access to landing points under low-light 
conditions at night and extensions and general improvements to selected airstrips are essential. 
 
9.  ADB’s  operational  strategy  for  the  Fiji  Islands  is  consistent  with  the  Government’s 
objectives and includes (i) promoting maximum use of the region’s potential, (ii) supporting 
infrastructure  and  commercial  development  and  investment  in  rural  areas,  (iii)  maintaining 
effective  social  services,  (iv)  encouraging  active  community  participation,  (v)  improving 
coordination and effectiveness of local administration, and (vi) reducing economic and social 
disparities  between  regions.  ADB’s  operational  strategy  identified  improvement  of  physical 
infrastructure as a priority area to support the strategic objectives, together with complementary 
assistance  for  rural  livelihoods  and  outer  islands  development.  Over  the  medium  term,  to 
promote growth, ADB will continue to emphasize improvement of the policy environment, and 
given  the  perennial  shortage  of  skills,  place priority  on  human  resource  development  and 
institutional strengthening of key sector agencies, and promote private sector development.

10.  The  project  preparatory  TA  will  help  the  Government  develop  and  assist  balanced 
regional development and reduce poverty. An initial poverty and social analysis is shown in 
Appendix 2. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The project preparatory TA is to help the Government design an investment project to 
improve income-earning opportunities and reduce economic disparities in the rural and outer 
islands—the eastern and central divisions of the Fiji Islands. The proposed project will support 
the Government's objectives of balanced regional development and distribution of economic 
opportunities to all parts of the Fiji Islands.  
 
12.  The output of the TA will be a detailed feasibility study for financing by ADB covering the 
scope; detailed costs; implementation arrangements; and analysis of the economic, social, 
environmental, institutional, and key sectors. The TA will (i) identify potential income-generating 
opportunities and priority infrastructure to support development, (ii) identify potential for private-
sector  collaboration  with  island  communities  to  develop  locally  available  resources  in  a 
sustainable  and  equitable  manner,  and  (iii)  evaluate  policy  and  institutional  constraints 
impacting outer islands development. Special attention will be paid to the needs of women and 
youth to identify income-earning opportunities for such groups.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
13.  The TA will be undertaken in two phases, using a full participatory approach. During the 
first  phase  (3  months),  the  consultant  team  will  (i)  review  the  wide  range  of  problems 
constraining  rural  and  outer  islands  development,  including  institutional  capacity,  current 
policies,  legislation,  and  role  and  performance  of  different  agencies;  (ii)  assess  scope  for 
potential  development;  (iii)  undertake  wide  stakeholder  consultations  and  social,    poverty, 
environmental,  and  other  necessary  surveys;  (iv)  evaluate  the  impact  of  existing  ongoing 
programs; (v) identify potential income-generating opportunities in different areas and sectors, 
based  on  each  island’s  natural  advantage  and  endowment,  and  the  necessary  support, 
including access to credit, market, processing, storage, and others; (vi) identify the necessary 
infrastructure to support economic development, including small jetties, rural roads, and other 
basic  facilities;  and  (vii)  assess  the  capacity  and  potential  of  the  private  sector  to  build 
partnerships  with  local  groups  to  participate  in  development  and  service  delivery.  Active 
consultations will be undertaken with the central, provincial, and local governments, community 
groups, and nongovernment organizations (NGOs).  
 
14.  During the second phase (2 months), the team, in consultation with the stakeholders, will 
prepare a comprehensive feasibility report. The report will cover in detail the components— 
financial, economic, social, and environmental; relevant sector analysis; role and institutional 
capacity of key stakeholders; appropriate procurement and implementation arrangements; and 
the cross-cutting issues of poverty reduction, gender, good governance, and private sector 
development. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The  total  cost  of  the  TA  is  estimated  to  be  US$994,000  equivalent,  comprising 
US$525,000  in  foreign  exchange  and  US$469,000  equivalent  in  local  currency.  The

4   
Government has requested ADB to finance US$700,000 equivalent to meet the entire foreign 
exchange cost of US$525,000 and US$175,000 equivalent of the local currency cost. The TA 
will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The Government will finance 
the balance of the local currency cost of US$294,000 equivalent by providing counterpart staff, 
support services, and office facilities. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are shown 
in Appendix 3. The Government has been informed that approval of the TA does not commit 
ADB to financing any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  The Ministry of Agriculture, Sugar, and Land Resettlement (MASLR)4, the Executing 
Agency (EA) for the TA, will coordinate closely with the Ministry of Finance and National 
Planning (MOFP), Ministry of Regional Development (MRD), Ministry of Fisheries and Forests, 
and Ministry of Works and Energy (MWE). MASLR will appoint a counterpart TA manager, and 
MOFP and MRD will also appoint counterpart staff for coordination between the Government, 
other stakeholders, and ADB consultants. A TA steering committee will be established and 
chaired by the chief executive officer of MASLR; it will also include senior representatives from 
MRD, MOFP, MWE, Ministry of Public Enterprises, Ministry of Transport and Civil Aviation, 
Prime Minister’s Office, and other relevant agencies. The steering committee will meet monthly 
to guide and support the TA team in the project preparation and also report regularly on the 
progress of the TA to the Cabinet subcommittee on agriculture.  
 
17.  The TA will be implemented in two phases (paras. 13−14), over a 5−month period, 
commencing around June 2005 and ending in October 2005. Substantial time will be devoted to 
field work, including stakeholder consultations and workshops. The consultant team will prepare 
an inception report within 2 weeks of commencement of field activities, and a midterm progress 
report at the end of the third month. A draft final report, in the format of a detailed feasibility 
report,  will  be  submitted  5  months  after  commencement  of  services.  Before  phase  2 
commences, 1 month is allowed to incorporate the decisions and views from the stakeholders to 
ensure ownership. The inception, midterm, and draft final reports will be subject to tripartite 
reviews by the Government, ADB and the consultants. 
 
18.  About 17 person-months of international and 10 person-months of domestic consultants 
will  be  required;  consultants  must  have  experience  in  rural  development,  agriculture, 
infrastructure, credit, economics, finance, environmental, and social assessment. To meet the 
Government’s  urgent  request  for  early  project  processing,  the  consultant  services  will  be 
provided by a team of individual consultants recruited in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the selection and 
engagement of domestic consultants. The outline of the consultants’ terms of reference is in 
Appendix 4. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of US$700,000 on a grant basis 
to the Government of the Fiji Islands for preparing the Rural and Outer Islands Development 
 
Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

INITIAL POVERTY AND SOCIAL ANALYSIS 
  
A.   Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis

country poverty analysis?  Yes.  country poverty partnership agreement? Yes. 
Contribution of the sector/subsector to reducing poverty in the Fiji Islands: 
 
More than half the people live in rural areas, and agriculture is the mainstay of the economy in terms of production 
value, employment and income generation, and subsistence. Some 25% households, or about 200,000 people, live 
in rural and outer island areas covering eastern and central divisions of the Fiji Islands. Most of the family members 
rely on subsistence economy, and main cash crops are copra and kava. A recent poverty assessment of hardship 
by ADB indicated that 35–40% of the population is likely to have incomes below the poverty line. 
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis      Targeting Classification: Targeted intervention 
What type of poverty analysis is needed? 
 
The latest official poverty analysis for Fiji Islands was undertaken by UNDP and published in 1997. The analysis 
was based on the 1990/91 HIES. New HIES were undertaken by the Fiji Bureau of Statistics for the urban centers in 
2002/03 and the rural areas in 2003/04. The data from these two household surveys are  now being analyzed by the 
Government. During project preparation, a participatory poverty survey and social analysis will be undertaken to 
determine the extent of poverty and priorities of the people in the remote outer islands. 
 
C.   Participation Process 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?                                        Yes 
 
Is there a participation strategy?                                        Yes 
 
The TA calls for broad stakeholder consultations.              
 
D.   Gender and Development 
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
Gender issues will be analyzed and integrated with the project design. Women have generally  played a major part 
in the subsistence economy but little in cash crop farming. They have  the potential to play an increased role in 
diversified agriculture, including in such areas as horticulture, floriculture, small marine resources handicrafts, small-
scale  processing,  and  micro-enterprises.  The  community-organizing  NGOs,  which  will  include  a  substantial 
percentage of women organizers, will seek to ensure effective participation by women in project activities. Skills 
training will involve women specifically targeting women’s income-generating skills.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTING SERVICES 
 
1.  The project preparatory technical assistance (TA) will be conducted in two phases. 
During phase 1 (3 months), diagnostic work will be undertaken, in consultation with a wide 
range of stakeholders, to assess the broad range of constraints and problems facing the rural 
and outer islands. Specifically, the TA will (i) review the wide range of problems constraining 
rural and outer islands development, including institutional capacity, current policies, legislation, 
and role and performance of different agencies; (ii) assess scope for potential development; (iii) 
undertake wide stakeholder consultations and conduct social, poverty, environmental, and other 
necessary surveys; (iv) evaluate the impact of existing ongoing programs; (v) identify potential 
income-generating opportunities in different areas and sectors, based on each island’s natural 
advantage and endowment, and the necessary support, including access to credit, market, 
processing, storage, and others; (vi) identify the necessary infrastructure─small jetties, rural 
roads,  and  other  basic  facilities─to  support  economic  development;  and  (vii)  assess  the 
capacity and potential of the private sector to build partnerships with local groups to participate 
in development and service delivery. Active consultations will be undertaken with the central, 
provincial,  and  local  governments;  community  groups;  and  nongovernment  organizations 
(NGOs).  
 
2.  During the second phase (2 months), the team, in consultation with the stakeholders, will 
prepare a comprehensive feasibility report. The report will cover in detail the components, 
financial, economic, social, environmental, and relevant sectors analysis; role and capacity of 
key stakeholders; appropriate procurement and implementation arrangements; and the cross-
cutting issues of poverty reduction, gender, good governance, and private sector participation. 
  
A.  International Consultants 
 
  1.  Rural Development Specialist/Team Leader (5.5 person-months)

regular consultations including the steering committee; 
(iii)  review  statistics  and  other  information  on  population,  migration,  land  use, 
employment,  business,  and  other  trends;  identify  the  policy  and  institutional 
constraints and changes needed; and, based on the review, assess the viability 
of such interventions and prepare an outer island development plan;  
(iv)  review the institutional capacity of various agencies, including the local agencies;

(ii)  recommend environmentally feasible crops and agribusiness ventures that  will

(ii)  based on the ongoing credit/finance services, review the viability of rural financial

considering the status of the beneficiaries, transaction costs, and the need to 
provide sustainable rural financial services; 
(v)  prepare  and  cost  the  rural  financial  services  component  to  address  the 
communities’ financial service needs, both savings and credit, including support 
for the agriculture, agribusiness, and other livelihood small and micro-enterprise 
ventures. 
 
  5.  Financial Analyst/Financial Management Specialist (1.5 person-months) 
 
7.  The consultant will 
(i)  complete an assessment of financial viability and sustainability analysis based on 
Guidelines  for  the  Financial  Governance  and  Management  of  Investment 
Projects financed by ADB; 
(ii)  review  project  cost  estimates  and  proposed  loan  drawdown  schedules  and, 
where appropriate, compute price contingencies and interest and other charges 
during construction; 
(iii)  assess the financial sustainability of project investments and, where appropriate, 
evaluate investments over the construction and operating period by calculating 
the  financial  internal  rate  of  return  (FIRR)  and  compare  it  with  a  weighted 
average cost of capital (WACC), both  computed on an after-tax basis in real 
terms, using constant 2004 prices; 
(iv)  undertake  a  financial  management  assessment  of  the  proposed  executing 
agency and project implementing agencies which should include: (a) corporate 
planning and budgetary control, (b) financial and management accounting, (c) 
cost accounting, (d) internal control and audit system, and (e) data processing 
and suggest appropriate financial covenants to monitor financial conditionalities 
for the project; 
(v)  in  the  light  of  ADB’s  Governance,  Sound  Development  Management  Policy, 
published  in  1995,  recommend  ways  to  improve  financial  management  and 
corporate governance; and

6.  Unallocated  for Various Other Expertise (1.0 person-month) 
 
B.  Domestic Consultants 
 
1.  Rural Infrastructure Specialist (3.5 person-months) 
 
8.  The consultant will 
(i)  in consultation with other team members and key stakeholders, review current 
infrastructure conditions in the rural areas of Vanua Levu and Viti Levu and in the 
outer islands, include existing development plans in the review with information 
on their present status; 
(ii)  determine  the  infrastructure  requirement,  including  location,  potential,  and 
economic  use  to  support  and  accelerate  income-generating  opportunities 
identified by the consultants and stakeholders in the isolated rural and outer 
islands communities; 
(iii)  review  the  inter-island  transportation  status  and  propose  options  to  improve 
services to outer islands; 
(iv)  incorporate  feedback  on  the  midterm  report  and  analyses  of  other  team 
members,  make  preliminary  designs  for  the  least-cost  options,  and  cost  the 
infrastructure requirements needed to service or develop areas with economic 
potential in various islands;  
(v)  verify that the proposed investment and all alternatives have been fully assessed 
to provide economic and technical justification for the selection of a specific 
technical option; 
(vi)  determine  the  ability  of  the  local  authorities  and  beneficiary  to  adequately 
maintain upgraded infrastructure and, with the Economist, review cost recovery 
options; 
(vii)  provide  costing  and  qualitative  and  quantitative  benefits  for  the  identified 
infrastructure; 
(viii)  identify  options  for  financing  and  assess  the  possibility  of  private  sector 
participation in the proposed construction and operation and maintenance; and 
(ix)   define  contract  packages  and  recommend  efficient  implementation  of  the 
infrastructure construction. 
 
2.  Rural Sociologist (3 person-months) 
 
9.  The consultant or the NGO will

collect  relevant  social  and  socioeconomic  information  and  statistics  and

women; 
(ii)  based on the findings, prepare a comprehensive analysis of the social conditions 
in project areas (including the capacity of the community members, individually 
and jointly, to participate in the different types of income-generating activities 
considered) and a poverty profile of the rural and outer islands communities, 
asset and income poverty, to determine the type of livelihood assistance needed, 
including details for potential participation by the poor, women, and youth;
